comments.commentBody:
Dr. K,
The US and Europe have much in common and they b elieve that we are one and interdependent. In puzzling over your question. I think it can be explained by the policy response to the financial blow out and the following recession. Our response was weak and the rhetoric leading up to the 2010, if I rccall was debt and deficit. The rhetorivc was from some very serous people including a former Fed Chairman. Then the newly elected T-Party sunk their teeth into the issue including the "gangs of X" and Bowles Simpson. They even had me believe that we were going to do a double-dip recession. So Europeans were not going to lead with monetary or fiscal stimulus, unless they were nuts. Many of your commenters are saying that the US has not really recovered. The Fed actions really just recovered the losses off those that had some skin in the market. It brought up our averages but was brutal toward those who lost their job and was too old to reclaim employment. As a result the concentratinn of income and stagnant wages has hollowed out America's sttrength. We will probably be very slow ourselves in recovering.

We should be rebuilding while money is cheap but we are not so I don't think Europe really knows the best policy.

My friend, the capital of your country is named after Gorge Washington who once said:
”I can only say that no man living wishes more sincerely than I do to see the abolition of (slavery)… But when slaves who are happy & content to remain with their present masters, are tampered with & seduced to leave them… it introduces more evils than it can cure."(Hirschfield,p187).

I believe that Historical figures should not be considered as simplistic as pure evil or pure good, they should be considered as great leaders with the limitation of their time and society. Otherwise, we give them an unjust judgement.

Dear Saudi guy in Canada,
Thank you for your comments. Americans are ignorant of the fact that others live and work and thrive with customs other than ours and freedoms that are different than ours. I am an American but have lived in many other countries. The late King did many things that were liberal within the context of Saudi society. My female friends in Jordan don't know why American women "torture" themselves with driving, housework, shopping, etc. Although I don't like everything that I hear about Saudi society and customs, I do understand that Abdullah made reforms that required courage. Thank you for trying to give xenophobic Americans some perspective.
In the sense of fighting "terrorism" it's still a success in that the Houthis will fight against al Qeda and ISIS, two "terrorist" groujps, based on their Sunni composition.

'And Europe will be paying the price for their self-indulgence for years, perhaps decades, to come.'

As America always payed the price for it's irresponsibility - and for years, perhaps decades to come.
And that is not the same moralistic lecture as Prof. Krugman tries to deliver to Europe - because Europe never will ruin the worlds economy with irresponsibility.

And if the main lesson the US and Prof. Krugman takes from the near collapse of 2008 is - to consume more - his and the US irresponsibility knows no end.

GR...The US big profits from the global economy has gone to the top 10 %, and that is then applied to our congress in the form of campaign donations and subsidies. Both are profiting, as the number of millionaires in congress has increased greatly.

Any attempt to rebalance this in favor of the majority of salaried Americans is just labeled class warfare and redistribution--but it's the top few who are redistributing.
Btw Krugman is in favor of free trade, as he said in a blog the other day. Other advanced countries have ways of mitigating the bad effects of globalization on their citizens, but he never mentions these. It's time our liberal columnists explained this to Americans, as another way of doing globalization.

"Do you really think the USA and allied countries could not crush bitcoin out of existence...?"

No, of course not.

Governments have tried mightily to crush Internet "pornography" (a thousand definitions, pick your favorite), Internet gambling, copyright infringement e.g., The Pirate Bay, various forms of "forbidden" knowledge and news, and the list goes on. They have failed at every turn. 5 minutes of reasonably competent search, and you can find whatever you seek.

It's that dang open systems architecture. Give people enough technical capability to use the Internet effectively for what governments want (mostly tax revenue), and they'll do everything else they want to do and the governments can go hang.

Liberty. It's the future. Deal with it.

It is not secure.

The mathematics have never been proven secure, despite what the boosters say. The software implementations have never been proven bug-free. The web sites and marketplaces have never been proven secure. Plenty of Bitcoins get stolen.

If Bitcoin were outlawed, would some people break the law and get away with it? Yes. Would Bitcoin become a major trading vehicle if the world's governments wanted to crush it? No.
What you describe is true of every illegal practice. Some will break the law but some will be hanged for doing so. And illegal activity is thus kept at a minimal level. The invention of the internet does not change this or make "liberty is the future" any more or less likely to be true than it was before the internet.

It is true that fundamentally money depends upon the faith that the giver and receiver have in the value of a coin or piece of paper rather than on the intrinsic worth of the material exchanged. But, it is one thing to trust money issued by the US or other major governments and another to trust money that comes from a shadowy computer.

Saima,

Every time we drill a new oil well we are speaking up against our "life long friends" in Saudi Arabia! (by the way as the King died today is that the end of "Life Long"?)

You are spot on, Bruce. People in the West cannot understand the depth of the conflict between the Shias and Sunnis (as well as all of the minor sects) or the current time in history of the conflict between the two. The present represents the best opportunity for the Shias to rise and try to take dominion over Islam in several hundred years. They will not give up until most of them are dead. The US is totally powerless to impact this battle, not just because it has no legitimacy, but because it does not have the moral capacity to decimate civilian populations within the war zones, whereas the Islamist do. They have not moral compunction to refrain from fostering mayhem and mass murder if they think it advances the cause of
Allah. Although it may be difficult to stand by and watch millions of innocents be slaughtered by radicals who believe in conflicting fairy tales, the US has no capacity to do anything about it.

This should be an editors choice comment even if I dont 100% agree with the last paragraph (I am not sure doom is certain) but the Muslim civil wars are obviously heating up.

"The Islamic world is realigning through bloodshed into Sunni and Shiite camps"

Unfortunately all things point to that being true and ever more so in the last 2 years.
"...except Egypt and Iran..." two Middle Eastern/Muslim countries ruled with an iron hand.  A bitter lesson for outsiders: leave the strong men alone.

There already is a severe Sunni/Shia war ongoing in Syria. Iraq has had much of its land conquered by radial Sunnis to the detriment of its Shia residents. Saudi Arabia heavily finances its proxy Sunni fighters while Iran finances their Shia proxies. Now this. Yemen has fallen apart and we have the Saudi/Iranian proxy connection in the middle of all of it.

The Islamic world is realigning through bloodshed into Sunni and Shiite camps, each vying for world domination of Islam. How many countries have to collapse under this pressure before we recognize that these are not isolated events, but part of a grand battle to control the Islamic world?

As bad as Al Qaeda is, they may be just a sideshow compared to the unfolding Sunni/Shia wars.

We must stop denying that the Islamic world is blowing apart. The collapse of Yemen will only spread because the entire region is in turmoil. Each government there is weak and unstable, except Egypt and Iran. We will not be able to stop the coming violence but we can help to steer the realignment, whatever that will be. Looks bad, very bad.
Sorry, correction: Ronald Noble ( not Robert )

Thank you for what you're doing.

Hope you may have success with Robert Noble.

By the way, neither the newspaper "Clarin" nor politician Elisa Carrió are very well respected in Argentina when it comes to commentary on Mrs. Kirchner.

Again, thanks, -Christopher (In Buenos Aires since 2004. Dual citizen with United States)

One does not have to be Indian and in India to criticise India.  One does not have to read my religion's book to criticise my religion.  Saudi Arabia is not a country that tolerates fair criticism.  Only those who safely live outside can criticise here.  How is that unfair?

One doesn't have to live in or belong to Saudi society to have valid opinions or perspective on that society.  Yes it's possible that in relation to Saudi society in general King Abdullah was a "moderate" whatever that means. But you don't need to be Saudi to express displeasure with the kingdom & it's role in spreading extremist Islam wahbism throughout the world. It is the font from which so much evil flows. Almost all violent Islamic extremist groups adhere to some version of this teaching even if many don't find Saudi society conservative enough in practice. They are allies of necessity & have played the west well with their oil, slick public relations & alliances with powerful groups & families. Specifically the Bushes come to mind, or do you really believe the first gulf war was about Kuwait & not Saudi oil & security.
One other thing, as the massacres at Charlie Hebdo demonstrate: Western values in regard to liberty and freedom of expression are superior to medieval nonsense.

Many of the people who have been critical in these letters are not Muslim and are not Saudi. Who are you to say that King Abdullah was not moderate? For Saudi Arabia he was moderate. He opened a graduate university in the Kingdom where men and women of all nationalities (including Saudi) can study in classes together. Westerners and Arabs and Asians all live and work and study together there. It's not easy and it's not perfect, but it's a huge step in Saudi Arabia. If you are Saudi and are displeased with the King, you have the right to be. If you are not, you are simply judging him from your own biased perspective without considering the desires of Saudis. Many (though not all) Saudi women do NOT want to drive, do not want the freedoms they see Western women have, and do not want what Western women want. Others do, of course, and are often prohibited from access to education or freedoms. I am not justifying the culture or the extremist religious views, but I am arguing that unless you are Saudi you cannot really say that this King was not moderate.

The faults of European policy makers cited in this excellent column are also the faults of austerity hawks in the United States, particularly Tea Party Republicans. Much as Europe is fortunate to have the ECB's Mario Draghi, the U.S. has been fortunate to have had Ben Bernanke and now Janet Yellen at the helm of the Fed. Monetary expansion has served as an economic safety net in the U.S., and Europe would benefit from a similar approach.

Even more important is the need for fiscal policy expansion. Monetary policy can do only so much. Additional spending is needed to drive jobs and economic growth in the U.S, as well as in the EU. After more than 6 years of misery, you'd think that policy makers and voters would catch on.
You can't handle the truth!

It's said that history often repeats itself-- first as tragedy, second as farce.

This Disunion series which began so promisingly in the darkening days of late 2010 by literally attempting to recreate in voice & tense & real time the march to war, now whimpers towards a near-farcical end, not acknowledging nor discussing truths of such massive national importance that one almost has to visualize some counter-intuitive spookiness of quantum physics like the two slit experiment just to grasp the bizarre degree to which contributors to Disunion have been bending over backwards of late, so close to the finish line, and recapitulating the betrayal of 1865 that included the senseless assassination of Lincoln and the shredding of his beautiful vision for the future, the repudiation of his Gettysburg Address, but most important of all-- the leaving behind of justice and civil rights for America's already "free" and soon-to-be "free" Blacks at the very doorstep to the 20th century in much the same way US Brig. Gen. Jefferson C. Davis disassembled that pontoon bridge and left to the vengeance of their oppressors hundreds of desperate self-emancipated black Americans who hoped for freedom on the banks of Ebenezer Creek, just 20 miles from the Atlantic Ocean, as we read about here just a few days ago.

Amicable collegiality over coffee at tweed-jacketed conferences? I'm OK, you're OK, bygones are bygones?

Or sell-outs for Peace In Our Time?

Do your jobs "scholars", tell the truth.

After losing her 44 year old husband to a massive heart attack five years ago, our daughter still has his voice on the house answering machine. She said her two children, now ages 16 and 19, still get great solace in hearing their Dad's voice. I really thought it was ghoulish and prolonged their grieving period longer than necessary. I was wrong.

They have all moved on these last years and there is a new man in our daughter's life. But he understands the loving remembrance that voice message makes in the family's live and to tell you the truth, it now makes us happy to listen to our deceased son-in-laws voice. Somehow, there is a life force in that voice that allows for a few moments of thoughtful contemplation that soothes the soul.

I'm a Saudi girl studying in the US. I have to apologize in advance for my English, but I felt the need to address a few things I don't find true in your comment. First, women can be lawyers. Bayan Al Zahran is the first lawyer and there are couple more now. Second, what you are saying about practicing any religion is a policy the country holds, but this policy is not enforced at all. I know in the Eastern provence there are many Shias and they are freely practicing their believe (this was not the case when King Fahd was ruling the country). Third, women can go to any doctors any times they want. I myself do this all the time. The country is not perfect. A lot more work needs to be done. King Abdullah could have worked a little bit faster in advancing the country, but we need to remember how chaotic the country was in King Fahd's period.
Three  women lawyers, well that is a different kettle of fish.  That brings them up to the 15th century, at least.  Break out the champagne.  Oh wait, that's illegal...
How about the Shite minority?  How are they treated?

It will truly be history the one who will judge, but few leaders ever had their country, poor at first, turn into a nation with the wealth that oil has bestowed to Saudi Arabia.

Yet, the kingdom today is a country without native industry, with exactly a single export (oil) extracted under the aegis of foreign corporations, with no native scientists or engineers, architects, artists, or entrepreneurs --it is a country where laborers are all foreigner second class citizens, and where the population that obtained an education almost exclusively focused on religious studies.

At the same time, half the population (women) have been left repressed --a resource of creativity and labor left untapped, and the average Saudi has been left uneducated, poor, and without a future.

With all that wealth, perhaps Saudi Arabia could have risen as a center of knowledge, innovation, and industry --a successful amalgam of Islamic tradition and a nation looking forward (as, for example, the Caliphs of Baghdad achieved while the Middle Ages smothered Europe).

Frankly, it all looks like the king's years have been, in the final analysis, far from successful.

When I hear the economic analysts looking for answers to fixing an economy that no longer works I am reminded of the Irish Starvation. Robert Peel the Conservative Prime Minister at the outset of the potato blight was bound and determined to send food to the Irish who were starving. Peel's Conservatives were divided those devoted to Adam Smith and the invisible hand left Peel Conservatives. John Russell a Whig became Prime Minister and proceeded to send copies of Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations to the starving illiterate unpropertied peasants of Ireland.
The Economist reported that Adam Smith's economic philosophy was the economic religion of Britain and so it was that between 1 and half and two and a half million Irish peasants perished from starvation, pestilence and abuse in Ireland. Ireland a country that during the starvation exported enough cattle to Europe and the Americas to easily feed all that perished in the Potato "famine."
When Rand Paul or Paul Ryan present their economic doctrine based on Smith's economic philosophy I am reminded of the National Film Board of Canada's 2012 documentary The Coffin Ship Hanna and how the descendants of survivors were unable to deal with the guilt from what really happened for 150 years. Will our descendants for the next 150 years have to live with the guilt of our failing to jettison an economic philosophy that shows us a promise of inflicting nothing but pain, suffering and death? We need a people first economy.
I was trying to think of a last name for Lassie for the shephard.

Mr. Strudwick the actor spelled his first name SHEPPERD; I agree that all the versions and variations on Shepherd are très confusing. At least they all start with SHEP.  Mr. Strudwick was born in Hillsborough, NC, just down the road from here.
I was a really big fan of Shepperd Strudwick, not to mention having a crush on him--a fine actor and a very sexy man.

My candidate for Clue-of-the-Year goes to 33D "Shepherd of old films" and I erroneously got hung up on Strudwick, if you recall the actors highly cultured name and equally distinguished countenance?

Despite the gelid inclusion of ESKIMO's, ICI and EIS, this FRIXWDP by Ed Sessa, it somehow amazingly managed to avoid leaving me cold!

OVA and Out...
CIAOS from Howie in Quincy

I cannot help but note that the comparison to South Africa is without merit. Saudi Arabia is a country of the immensely wealthy through the good fortune of sitting on a sea of oil. Yet it oppresses terribly its supposedly fellow Arab Muslims from the Gaza, using them essentially as slaves that can be disposed of when no longer needed or able to work. South Africa's indigenous population lived in abject poverty under white rule, and that has not changed.

The statement "Saudi Arabia stands out . . .has also funded terrorism outside its borders, unlike South Africa" is nonsensical. South Africa has nothing to fund terrorism with, so we can't say anything about its motivation in not doing so.

Striking while the iron is hot? Again, nonsensical. With all the increasing oil production in the USA and Canada (which so many Times commenters criticisize as not being "environmentally friendly"), the Saudis still control the price of sweet crude in the open market. Some believe the reason they've lowered the price is to make producing oil from tar sands and fracking unprofitable and so slow our quest for independence from their good graces. Maybe so. But it has also put teeth into Obama's otherwise vacuous economic threats to Russia by reducing Russia's main source of foreign monies, exporting oil. Without that, Putin would still be slouched in his chair in contempt.

This is not good news, but in association with the death of King Abdullah in Saudi Arabia, it brings into focus that we cannot control this region, and we have had a miserable experience when we have tried. With American access to petroleum being much less acute than it was a decade ago, we as a nation need to make the decision as to this area of the world is of vital importance to the United States.
Yes, of course, Israel is there, but is that a vital interest of the US? I actually don't know. It would, however, be a refreshing debate as to whether American and Western interests in the Mideast are in jeopardy. If they are, from terrorism, to the proliferation to nuclear weapon. to women's rights, let's have a discussion of the problem, and if we even need to be involved, and if so, how?.
We certainly did not help the situation with our adventure in Iraq. But that is beside the case. What should we do now, and how should we do it? If we cannot come up with a coherent answer and strategy to that question, than that itself is an answer.
Not a chance. Research the petrodollar.
Agree. We must eliminate all Saudi and Yemeni oil wells. Problem solved.
Very worrisome development.  USA needs to take advantage of the current low oil prices to pivot toward new energy sources so that we can extricate ourselves from the mad politics of this region.

A politician is a professional. She, or he, is like a bookmaker, somebody who takes bets. In this case, the bets are on those policies who will benefit those who have the money, that is, the power.

The most powerful nation, the USA, ruthlessly led by its plutocracy. The bubble of 2008 transferred massive winnings from bets by some plutocrats against their peers and against giant money center banks which were public in two ways: on the stock exchanges, and, more importantly, as the organizations in charge of creating most of the money (through the extension of credit).

The bubbles popped. The financial system, throughout the world, was bankrupt. To fix it, the Central Banks enabled the creation of massive new credit (=money), by lowering interest rates to zero. The money center banks were then free to re-enact their previous act, and re-invest massively in financial derivatives, same as before, but now even more.

True, Obama dispersed a few hundred billions of “stimulus”. Much more money went from the Fed to the money center banks, trillions of dollars of it. One started, just as before.

A lot of the wealth of the USA comes from fracking (a gift from god), Wall Street conspiracies, and worldwide tax dodging by giant USA monopolies, all of this with the complicity of the world’s most powerful capitals, Washington and New York.

Is the European elite culprit? Sure. It was bought into the mood, and money, coming from the USA. So it saw nothing, it wanted to see nothing.

"Btw, our fiscal deficits improved because our private sector is much stronger"

The financial sector is stronger. There are a few more crumbs falling off the table, but the majority of us are simply learning to live with miserable wages,

Maybe that was the plan all along.

Injecting fluid capital into the market would have stepped up demand, increasing the amount of growing businesses and recouping the stimulus funds in increasing tax revenues. It's worked before and it will work again if the ideologues will just do a little reading and grow out of their rut.

Your comments are to be applauded.  They are written out of deep respect for a King you admired, whom you think has left a great legacy.  I can certainly agree with the legacy he has left to those who are gaining a higher education because it is widely known that education leads to enlightened thinking, change & growth.  Perhaps his educational gifts will be his greatest legacy to people of Saudi Arabia.

In Florida, programs like food stamps, Social Security, Medicaid for children (however inadequate), and Medicare did a great deal to keep the state from the sort of catastrophe that befell Spain.

Meanwhile the state and local governments were slashing spending. Any number of road projects, new schools, new courthouses, whatever, were cancelled. The state refused funds for Tampa to Orlando high speed rail, notwithstanding that Interstate 4 had been rebuilt to accommodate the tracks. Orlando's economy benefitted from the deep pockets behind Disney, Universal, and a local hotel chain, Rosen. They all saw the recession as an opportunity to build cheaply.

You do not change Rome overnight? Well, tell that to Charlemagne, Peter the Great, to Catherine of Russia, to Napoleon, to Augustus, to FDR, to Lincoln,  Elizabeth I... Ahem, the king was not as great as those men and women? Well, perhaps not, but this eulogy does read as the King belongs among these great men and women.
